thread.title: 'NYT' reporter in trouble for spreading 'unfounded rumor' about Melania Trump
thread.title_full: 'NYT' reporter in trouble for spreading 'unfounded rumor' about Melania Trump

author: Maria Puente , USA TODAY
title: 'NYT' reporter in trouble for spreading 'unfounded rumor' about Melania Trump
text:
Emily Ratajkowski (L) and Alexa Chung at the Altuzarra show during New York Fashion Week on Feb. 12, 2017 in New York. (Photo: Astrid Stawiarz, Getty Images)
4134 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 69 COMMENT EMAIL MORE A New York Times reporter was reprimanded for referring to "an unfounded rumor" about first lady Melania Trump, after model/actress Emily Ratajkowski tweet-tattled on Monday that the unnamed reporter called FLOTUS a "hooker."
On Monday afternoon, after Ratajkowski's tweets called out the reporter for "slut shaming" and "disgusting, sexist" tripe, the Times , which has been under steady attack from President Trump for months, issued a statement via spokeswoman Eileen Murphy.
"At a party last night, a Times reporter who does not cover Washington or politics, referred to an unfounded rumor regarding Melania Trump. The comment was not intended to be public, but it was nonetheless completely inappropriate and should not have occurred. Editors have talked to the reporter in question about the lapse."
First lady Melania Trump, and Akie Abe, wife of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, tour Morikami Museum and Japanese Gardens in Delray Beach, Fla., on Feb. 11, 2017. (Photo: Terry Renna, AP)
According to Ratajkowski's tweets, she sat next to a "NYT reporter" at an event Sunday night during New York Fashion Week where the reporter called Mrs. Trump the negative term.
"Whatever your politics, it's crucial to call this out for what it is: slut shaming," Ratajkowski ( Gone Girl ) said in her tweets.
Sat next to a journalist from the NYT last night who told me "Melania is a hooker." Whatever your politics it's crucial to call this out for
— Emily Ratajkowski (@emrata) February 13, 2017 what it is: slut shaming. I don't care about her nudes or sexual history and no one should.
— Emily Ratajkowski (@emrata) February 13, 2017 Mrs. Trump's past has been in the news recently because she's just refiled a $150 million libel suit (unprecedented for a sitting first lady) against the British tabloid Daily Mail 's website for reporting that the first lady once worked for modeling agencies that also operated as escort agencies.
USA TODAY
Melania Trump's 'Daily Mail' lawsuit: A FLOTUS first?
There is no evidence this is true, and Trump and her lawyers have denounced the report as 100% false. The Mail subsequently retracted the story but Trump is pursuing a lawsuit anyway, claiming the false story had damaged her "brand" and her ability to profit from her fame and position.
Perhaps this was what the reporter was referring to, and perhaps it was a shock to Ratajkowski, 25. In any case, she expressed her outrage to her 979,000 Twitter followers.
The fracas embarrassed the NYT at a time when it is already under steady fire, along with the rest of the mainstream media, for allegedly being unfair and biased against Trump.
Mrs Trump issued a statement late Monday: "Applause to all women around the world who speak up, stand up and support other women.”
Facebook Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Melania Trump through the years: Meet the new first lady Fullscreen Post to Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed.
First lady Melania Trump during a tour of the Morikami Museum and Japanese Gardens in Delray Beach, Fla., on Feb. 11, 2017. Terry Renna, AP Fullscreen During the Mar-a-Lago weekend with the Japanese prime minister, President Trump and first lady Melania Trump hosted the Japanese delegation at a private dinner on Feb. 11, 2017. The presidential couple posed at their Mar-a-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Fla., before the dinner. NICHOLAS KAMM, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Melania Trump wore a sleeveless black cocktail dress with lace bodice and hem to the Feb. 11 dinner with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and his wife Akie Abe at Trump's Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach. NICHOLAS KAMM, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Melania Trump's first opportunity for an official first lady role was touring a Japanese garden in Delray Beach, Fla., with Akie Abe, wife of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who stayed with the Trumps at their Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach. GASTON DE CARDENAS, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen According to the White House pool report, Mrs. Trump wore a tight, white, ankle-length dress, paired with nude flats and a white sweater draped over her shoulders. Abe wore a white button down shirt, an A-line skirt and pumps. Terry Renna, AP Fullscreen On Friday night, after the two couples arrived in West Palm Beach, the Trumps hosted the Abes and other guests, including Robert Kraft (2nd-L), owner of the New England Patriots, at a dinner at Mar-a-Lago, on Feb. 10, 2017. NICHOLAS KAMM, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen President Trump speaks to the press with first lLady Melania Trump aboard Air Force One on Feb. 10, 2017 during a flight to Trump's Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Fla., where they will host Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and his wife Akie Abe. NICHOLAS KAMM, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Melania was wearing white wide-legged palazzo pants and a black top when she joined President Trump and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and his wife Akie Abe, at the top of the stairs to Air Force One at Andrews Air Force Base Md., Feb. 10, 2017. Jose Luis Magana, AP Fullscreen The first lady went casual for the Super Bowl party at Trump International Golf Club in West Palm Beach, Fla., in white cropped skinny slacks, a sheer light blue V-necked sweater and white heels. The party capped a long weekend in Florida for the Trumps, and marked Melania Trump's first photographed appearance in public since the day after her husband's inauguration. She is expected to remain in Trump Tower in New York until June when her 10-year-old son finishes the school year. Susan Walsh, AP Fullscreen First lady Melania Trump surfaced for the first time in public since Jan. 21 on February 4, when she accompanied President Trump to the 60th Annual Red Cross Gala at their Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach. MANDEL NGAN, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Melania wore a pink Dior gown that emphasized her curvy figure to the Red Cross Gala, along with emerald and diamond earrings and ring. The gown featured a deep V neck and a slit up the front, revealing her sky-high pink stilettos. MANDEL NGAN, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Melania and President Trump flew in on Air Force One to the Palm Beach International Airport on Feb. 3 for a weekend at their Mar-a-Lago estate. She was wearing a red mini dress with cape sleeves by Givenchy and red flats. Joe Raedle, Getty Images Fullscreen Before returning to New York with her 10-year-old son, first lady Melania Trump accompanied her husband to the National Prayer Service at the National Cathedral in Washington, DC, on Jan. 21, 2017. She wore a belted black coat and cobalt blue Christian Louboutin spike heels. OLIVIER DOULIERY, Pool, EPA Fullscreen President Trump and first lady Melania Trump dance during the Freedom Ball at the Washington DC Convention Center. JIM WATSON, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Melania Trump collaborated with Herve Pierre, the former creative director of Carolina Herrera, on her tailored off-the-shoulder gown in vanilla silk, with a red ribbon at her waist and a big ruffle floating diagonally across the bodice. MOLLY RILEY, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen First lady Melania Trump wore a sky blue Ralph Lauren ensemble, complete with matching gloves, while attending her husband's inaugural ceremony. SHAWN THEW, EPA Fullscreen Her hair in a sleek updo, the first lady's pumps matched her designer look. Pool, Getty Images Fullscreen On the eve of Donald Trump's inauguration, Melania wore a gold Reem Acra dress at a dinner with campaign donors held at Union Station. MANDEL NGAN, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Americans got a new glimpse of incoming first lady Melania Trump, the first since Dec. 31, when she and President-elect Trump arrived at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland outside Washington D.C. on Jan. 19, 2017, one day before his swearing-in. Chris Kleponis, Pool, Getty Images Fullscreen Melania wore sunglasses, high heels and a fitted black skirt suit for the arrival ceremony at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland outside Washington. MANDEL NGAN, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen President-elect Donald Trump and Melania Trump arrive for a GOP leadership luncheon at the Trump International Hotel in Washington, DC on January 19, 2017. MANDEL NGAN, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen At the luncheon, Trump invited Melania to speak. She said, "Tomorrow we're starting the work," adding that "there's "a lot of possibility and a lot to take care of." Chris Kleponis / POOL, EPA Fullscreen Melania Trump stands in front of other Trump family members at a wreath-laying ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery on Jan. 19, 2017. MANDEL NGAN, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen There was a new Melania Trump sighting on New Year's Eve in Palm Beach, Fla. The incoming new first lady has been mostly unseen since shortly after husband Donald Trump was elected, and when she does turn up it's beside the president-elect. That was the case Saturday night as they arrived for a New Year's Eve party at their estate Mar-a-Lago. DON EMMERT, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen For the party, Melania donned a fitted black cocktail dress by Dolce & Gabbana, featuring a low-cut tank-top-style bodice embellished with bows pinned with elaborate brooches, and a below-the-knee hem with a split up the front. DON EMMERT, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Melania goes to Washington. President-elect Trump (C), with his wife and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell after a meeting in at the Capitol on Nov. 10. SHAWN THEW, EPA Fullscreen Melania Trump was included in the sit-down shot with Speaker of the House Paul Ryan and Vice-president-elect Mike Pence, after a meeting in the Speaker's office at the Capitol. Alex Brandon, AP Fullscreen The Trumps got a view of the inaugural stand under construction from the Speaker's Balcony. Mrs. Trump wore a double-breasted black coat and skirt, plus Christian Louboutin high heels. Alex Brandon, AP Fullscreen Melania Trump (L) and elder Trump daughter Ivanka Trump on election night at the New York Hilton Midtown in New York. JIM WATSON, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Melania wore a white pantsuit ensemble by Ralph Lauren on election night, here with her husband, her son Barron, plus Jared Kushner and his wife Ivanka Trump, and Tiffany Trump. Evan Vucci, AP Fullscreen President-elect Donald Trump greets Melania after speaking at the New York Hilton Midtown in New York on election night Nov. 8, 2016. Saul Loeb, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Melania arrives for the grand opening of the new Trump International Hotel on Oct. 26, 2016 in Washington, DC. Chip Somodevilla, Getty Images Fullscreen Donald Trump and Melania Knauss, before their marriage, toast the new year during Trump's gala on Jan. 1, 2000, in Palm Beach, Fla. Scott Fisher, AP Fullscreen Donald and Melania Trump pose in their formal wear for the Entertainment Industry Foundation's National Colorectal Cancer Research Alliance evening back in April 2004. Stuart Ramson, AP Fullscreen Melania Trump waves to the crowd after her wedding to Donald Trump at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda by the Sea on Jan. 22, 2005, in Palm Beach, Fla. JOE AMON, AP Fullscreen The Trumps on the red carpet during arrivals at the 64th annual Golden Globe Awards at the Beverly Hilton Hotel on Jan. 15, 2007. Dan MacMedan, USAT Fullscreen In this photo released by FAO Schwarz, Donald Trump, Melania Trump and their son Barron, 2, attend the 17th annual Bunny Hop on March 11, 2008, in New York. Diane Bondareff, AP Fullscreen Donald Trump, Ivanka Trump, Melania Trump and Barron Trump attend the "The Trump Card: Playing to Win in Work and Life" book launch celebration at Trump Tower on Oct. 14, 2009, in New York City. Andrew H. Walker, Getty Images Fullscreen Melania Trump arrives at the 83rd Annual Academy Awards at the Kodak Theatre in Los Angeles on Feb. 27, 2011. Dan MacMedan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Trumps on the sidelines before an an NFL game between the New York Jets and the New England Patriots on Nov. 13, 2011, in East Rutherford, N.J. Bill Kostroun, AP Fullscreen Donald Trump waves as he walks with his wife, Melania, before announcing that he is running for president on June 16, 2015, in New York. Justin Lane, European Pressphoto Agency Fullscreen Melania Trump listens to her husband speak to the media in the spin room after the CNBC Republican debate on Oct. 28, 2015, in Boulder, Colo. Andrew Burton, Getty Images Fullscreen Donald Trump is joined by his wife, Melania Trump, as speaks during a campaign event on Feb. 1, 2016, in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Mary Altaffer, AP Fullscreen Melania Trump speaks during a South Carolina Republican primary night event on Feb. 20, 2016, in Spartanburg, S.C. Paul Sancya, AP Fullscreen The Trumps meet the press after the Republican debate at the University of Miami on March 11, 2016. Craig Rubadoux, Florida Today Fullscreen Ivanka Trump and Melania Trump listen to Donald Trump speak after the New York primary on April 19, 2016, at Trump Tower. Carucha L. Meuse, The Journal News Fullscreen Melania Trump listens as her husband delivers remarks following primary wins on June 7, 2016, at Trump National Golf Club Westchester in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Kena Betancur, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Donald Trump greets his wife, Melania Trump, on stage during the 2016 Republican National Convention at Quicken Loans Arena. Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Trumps hug at the end of the first presidential debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y., on Sept. 26, 2016. Joe Raedle, European Pressphoto Agency Fullscreen Former president Bill Clinton greets Melania Trump before the start of the second presidential debate at Washington University in St. Louis on Oct. 9, 2016. Paul J. Richards, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Trump is cheered by wife Melania and daughter Ivanka after the final presidential debate in Las Vegas on Oct. 19, 2016. Joe Raedle, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Melania Trump speaks during a rally for her husband on Nov. 3, 2016, at the Main Line Sports Center in Berwyn, Pa. Mandel Ngan, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump and his wife Melania cast their ballots at PS-59, Tuesday, Nov. 8, 2016, in New York.
